dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Flashman and the bullies carry Tom, still struggling down corridor. *

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There is still a fire glowing in the hearth, throwing a d orange light around the room. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 29 Tom Brown's Schooldays - Shooting Script 06.04.04 25A.

dialogues.speaker: FLASHMAN
dialogues.text: Into the blanket with him. A large blanket is produced and stretched out and Tom is onto it. He is on his back staring up at the ceiling. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tom Brown's Schooldays - Shooting Script 06.04.04 26.

dialogues.speaker: FLASHMAN
dialogues.text: One. Two. Three! They throw Tom high into the air, his arms flailing. He lands back in the blanket.

dialogues.speaker: FLASHMAN
dialogues.text: Again! Tom is sent high up into the air again, he tries to fight his head bangs against the ceiling to cheers from the Fif

dialogues.speaker: FLASHMAN
dialogues.text: One for luck. Tom starts to fight his way off of the blanket, gets roug pushed back.

dialogues.speaker: EAST
dialogues.text: Don’t fight it, Tom. Lay still! They all turn to see East standing in the doorway, concer his friend.

dialogues.speaker: FLASHMAN
dialogues.text: Mr East. I do believe I told you stay in your dorm.

dialogues.speaker: EAST
dialogues.text: He’s hit the ceiling, Flashman, now let him alone. Flashman surveys East with amusement.

dialogues.speaker: FLASHMAN
dialogues.text: Let’s toss the two of ‘em together. Speedicot and others manhandle East into the blanket with

dialogues.speaker: FOTHERGILL
dialogues.text: (Concerned) Bit dangerous, Flashy.

dialogues.speaker: FLASHMAN
dialogues.text: (To Fothergill) And your point is? Fothergill shrugs, leaves the room.

dialogues.speaker: EAST
dialogues.text: (To Tom) Lie still. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 29 30 31 Tom Brown's Schooldays - Shooting Script 06.04.04 27.

dialogues.speaker: FLASHMAN
dialogues.text: One. Two. Three! The blanket is tightened and the two boys fly into the ai banging and tangling against each other.

dialogues.speaker: EXT
dialogues.text: Arnold is taking the air in the still of the night, Spot running ahead. A noise alerts Arnold to the kerfuffle in the School Hous The fire in the room makes monstrous shadows of what is happening to Tom and East.

dialogues.speaker: FLASHMAN
dialogues.text: Again! The boys are thrown hard into the air and Tom’s face smas against the ceiling. Tom and East fall back down and this time the blanket mis Tom, who hits his back against the hard wooden floor.

dialogues.speaker: SPEEDICOT
dialogues.text: I think he’s had enough, Flashy.

dialogues.speaker: FLASHMAN
dialogues.text: Nonsense. You wouldn’t want us to think you were a little girly, now, would you Brown? Flashman takes Tom’s hair and shakes his head for him.

dialogues.speaker: FLASHMAN
dialogues.text: There you see! Suddenly the door bursts open and FOTHERGILL is standing a look of terror on his face.

dialogues.speaker: FOTHERGILL
dialogues.text: The Doctor! The boys look very scared. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tom Brown's Schooldays - Shooting Script 06.04.04 27A.

dialogues.speaker: FLASHMAN
dialogues.text: Not a word, Brown. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 31 32 33 Tom Brown's Schooldays - Shooting Script 06.04.04 28.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Flashman and Speedicot and the others pour out of the doo make good their escape. Tom lies stunned and confused on the floor as East tries him up.

dialogues.speaker: EAST
dialogues.text: Hurry, Tom! But Tom is dazed, doesn’t know where he is. East glances at the door, knows they are about to be caug

dialogues.speaker: EAST
dialogues.text: Say nothing! East hates to do it but he escapes whilst he has time. A beat. Tom shakes his head, feels the blood trickling from his n He sees the shoes first. Black, shiny, impeccable. Then he looks up the body to the stern eyes of Doctor Arn Rugby staring down at him.

dialogues.speaker: EXT
dialogues.text: The school is quiet in the still of the night.

dialogues.speaker: CUT TO
dialogues.text: INT - RUGBY SCHOOL/ARNOLD’S STUDY - NIGHT 33 Tom sits uncomfortably as Arnold cleans the dried blood f face.

dialogues.speaker: ARNOLD
dialogues.text: What’s your name?

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: Brown, sir. Thomas Brown. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tom Brown's Schooldays - Shooting Script 06.04.04 28A.

dialogues.speaker: ARNOLD
dialogues.text: Who were the perpetrators of this little act of horse-play, Brown? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 33 34 Tom Brown's Schooldays - Shooting Script 06.04.04 29.

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: I don’t know, sir.

dialogues.speaker: ARNOLD
dialogues.text: You don’t know or you won’t tell me? Tom says nothing. The door opens and a sleepy Mary comes into the room.

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: What's happened?

dialogues.speaker: ARNOLD
dialogues.text: Go back to bed, dear.

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: Is he hurt? Mary fusses over to Tom, looks at his face.

dialogues.speaker: ARNOLD
dialogues.text: It’s nothing, just a tumble. Tom hates all this attention.

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: Please, sir, may I go back to my dorm? Arnold just looks at him, feels some sympathy.

dialogues.speaker: ARNOLD
dialogues.text: Go on. Tom hurries towards the door, desperate to get away.

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: Good night, sir. Ma’am. And with that Tom is gone with a crash of the door.

dialogues.speaker: INT
dialogues.text: The great chapel is crowded with all the boys in the scho atmosphere is tight with interest and expectation. Arnold is at his lectern, the Masters behind him. Frobisher and the Sixth line the walls. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tom Brown's Schooldays - Shooting Script 06.04.04 29A.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Tom is sat between East and Tadpole. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tom Brown's Schooldays - Shooting Script 06.04.04 30.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Flashman buffs his nails.

dialogues.speaker: ARNOLD
dialogues.text: It is my most sincere desire to make this school a place of Christian education. What do I mean by this? There is no place or time from which Religion is shut out, there is no place or time where we cannot be serving God by serving our fellow- creatures. Flashman yawns theatrically and Speedicot, Fothergill and of the others snicker.

dialogues.speaker: ARNOLD
dialogues.text: Roughness, coarseness, want of feeling, unkindness, cruelty, bullying, these qualities bear no resemblance to the inhabitants of the Kingdom of God and will not be tolerated in this school. Tom watches Arnold at work, oddly fascinated.

dialogues.speaker: ARNOLD
dialogues.text: The false tongue; the violent hand; the proud or covetous thought; the indolent temper; the unkind or unjust or selfish action. None of these things will be tolerated. Arnold lets his words echo around the chapel.

dialogues.speaker: ARNOLD
dialogues.text: I will believe each and every boys’ word as I would believe a man’s. A shake of the head from Lampard, who is hating this.

dialogues.speaker: ARNOLD
dialogues.text: I will believe what you tell me. But I tell you now, gentleman, that if you think this trust on my part is a license for lying and deception you will be deeply disappointed. I hope we understand each other. The boys stop fidgeting, hear the threat in Arnold’s voic Arnold seems to look directly at Tom now, who squirms on bench. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 34 35 Tom Brown's Schooldays - Shooting Script 06.04.04 31.

dialogues.speaker: ARNOLD
dialogues.text: Remember this: your greatest bond is to God, not to your companions. It is no disgrace for the bullied to come forward and point a finger at the bully. In fact it is his duty, to the school, to me and to God. It is the only way we will rid this place of the vicious, cowardly practice of systematic bullying. Some of the younger boys look back at Flashman.

dialogues.speaker: ARNOLD
dialogues.text: To these ends I have initiated some initial reforms. There will be no more horses kept at the school. The beagle pack will be disbanded forthwith. The older boys look appalled at this development.

dialogues.speaker: ARNOLD
dialogues.text: There will be no firearms held by any boy. There will be no gambling. There will be no production or imbibing of alcohol of any kind. The middle boys look at each other now, equally appalled. Lampard and some of the other Masters barely bother to hi their contempt.

dialogues.speaker: ARNOLD
dialogues.text: This will be a great school, a Christian School for Christian gentleman, a place of light and learning and goodness. The boys look at each other, rebellion in their minds.

dialogues.speaker: ARNOLD
dialogues.text: Let us pray.

dialogues.speaker: EXT
dialogues.text: Two fit young schoolboy RUNNERS scatter paper from bags b on to their bodies.

dialogues.speaker: CUT TO
dialogues.text: 36 Tom Brown's Schooldays - Shooting Script 06.04.04 32.

dialogues.speaker: EXT
dialogues.text: Tom, East and Tadpole - in their running kit - hurry through the arch of the school towards a group of fifty or so assembl schoolboy runners of older boys. Tom looks excited, keen, East and Tadpole a bit less so.

dialogues.speaker: TADPOLE
dialogues.text: Nine miles! Over dashed hard ground.

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: Stop whining, Tadpole.

dialogues.speaker: EAST
dialogues.text: Think of the bread and cheese and punch if we make it.

dialogues.speaker: TADPOLE
dialogues.text: We won’t make it. The boys reach the gaggle of runners who are listening to Frobisher Frobisher Frobisher as he outlines the race.

dialogues.speaker: FROBISHER
dialogues.text: The hares have been given a six minute start. Any fellow that comes in within fifteen minutes of them will dine at the “Hop Pole” tonight. sees Tom, East and Tadpole arrive.

dialogues.speaker: FROBISHER
dialogues.text: Aren’t you three a bit young?

dialogues.speaker: TADPOLE
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: We can do it. looks at his watch. Waits.

dialogues.speaker: FROBISHER
dialogues.text: We're off! The runners - Tom, East and Tadpole included - start spri off in the direction of the open countryside.

dialogues.speaker: CUT TO
dialogues.text: 37 38 Tom Brown's Schooldays - Shooting Script 06.04.04 33.

dialogues.speaker: EXT
dialogues.text: Frobisher and the older, stronger boys are already sprint ahead. The pack struggle behind them. The trail goes cold for a moment as Frobisher and the oth leaders look for the scattered paper.

dialogues.speaker: BOY
dialogues.text: There! The Boy points to where the Hares are heading up a plough dark field towards the tree-line.

dialogues.speaker: FROBISHER
dialogues.text: Forward! Again the stronger runners sprint ahead. Tom has to cajole East and Tadpole to keep up.

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: Come on! A rumble of thunder. Tadpole slips, starts feeling his ankle. Tom looks ahead, sees the other boys almost out of sight

dialogues.speaker: EXT
dialogues.text: Tom, Tadpole and East run up to an ancient, dilapidated b East is about to step into the barn when he steps back, e wide with excitement.

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: What is it? East puts his finger over his lips for silence. He hurries around the back of the barn as Tom and Tadpole him, puzzled.

dialogues.speaker: TADPOLE
dialogues.text: I’m not in the mood for games, East. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tom Brown's Schooldays - Shooting Script 06.04.04 33A.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: East glares at Tadpole, insists on silence. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 38 Tom Brown's Schooldays - Shooting Script 06.04.04 34.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: East starts to climb the ladder, followed by an intrigued and a grumpy Tadpole. There is a hole in the roof of the barn and the three boy down through it. Down below is the familiar figure of Flashman. He is talk Sally, who looks very nervous, very distressed.

dialogues.speaker: FLASHMAN
dialogues.text: Come on, Sally, don’t be a spoilsport. Flashman walks towards her as Sally backs off.

dialogues.speaker: SALLY
dialogues.text: Can we go home, please, sir?

dialogues.speaker: FLASHMAN
dialogues.text: Just one little kiss?

dialogues.speaker: SALLY
dialogues.text: Maybe after we’re engaged.

dialogues.speaker: FLASHMAN
dialogues.text: Didn’t I buy you a pretty necklace?

dialogues.speaker: SALLY
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: FLASHMAN
dialogues.text: Shouldn't a chap get a little reward for a pretty necklace? Flashman uses his silver-topped cane to part Sally’s blou

dialogues.speaker: SALLY
dialogues.text: (Very upset) Please don’t. Suddenly the rotten roof gives way and poor Tadpole crash through it, his fall broken by a pile of hay. Flashman looks around, astonished at this interruption. Sally sees that his attention has been diverted and makes for it, running out of the barn. Flashman turns to deal with Tadpole, a furious sneer on h face.

dialogues.speaker: TADPOLE
dialogues.text: (Weak) Hello, Flashman. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 38 39 Tom Brown's Schooldays - Shooting Script 06.04.04 35.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Flashman smashes the tip of his cane into the palm of his and advances on Tadpole.

dialogues.speaker: TADPOLE
dialogues.text: Please, Flashy. Tom and East watch, helpless, as Flashman walks towards t terrified Tadpole.

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: Flashman! Up here! Flashman looks up, startled to see East and Tom looking d him. Tadpole turns and runs out of the back of the barn.

dialogues.speaker: FLASHMAN
dialogues.text: (To Tom) You'll keep, Brown. With that Flashman walks quickly through the barn to foll Tadpole. East and Top crane their necks to see Tadpole legging it direction of the river, with Flashman hurrying after him, possessed.

dialogues.speaker: EXT
dialogues.text: Tadpole is exhausted, has come to a halt on the bank of t wide, swift-running river. He turns to see Flashman walking slowly towards him.

dialogues.speaker: TADPOLE
dialogues.text: I didn’t see anything. Honest, I didn't.

dialogues.speaker: FLASHMAN
dialogues.text: I’m going to kill you, you dirty little scud, and feed you to the fishes.

dialogues.speaker: TADPOLE
dialogues.text: Please, Flashy. I'll fag for you all year. I'll - Flashman advances towards him, Tapping his can in the pal his hand. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tom Brown's Schooldays - Shooting Script 06.04.04 35A.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Tadpole starts to edge back along a branch that reaches o the river. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 39 Tom Brown's Schooldays - Shooting Script 06.04.04 36.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: East and Tom are running across the field towards them.

dialogues.speaker: TADPOLE
dialogues.text: Please don’t hurt me, Flashman. Tadpole steps back in fear. The branch is rotten, gives w under his weight, and Tadpole plunges into the current.

dialogues.speaker: EAST
dialogues.text: Tadpole! Tadpole is thrashing about in the river, very frightened.

dialogues.speaker: EAST
dialogues.text: He can’t swim. Flashman looks nervous now.

dialogues.speaker: FLASHMAN
dialogues.text: He shouldn’t creep up on a chap.

dialogues.speaker: EAST
dialogues.text: He’s going under! Tom sees Tadpole’s head disappear under the surface of th water. Without hesitation Tom runs and jumps into the water, swi across the current towards Tadpole’s flailing hands. East and Flashman watch as Tom reaches Tadpole. But Tadpole is so terrified that he is pulling Tom under East starts sprinting along the river bank, trying to get of his friends. Flashman looks around, makes sure no-one else has seen an this, and then hurriedly slopes away from the scene. East runs ahead of the struggling boys, sees a weir.

dialogues.speaker: EAST
dialogues.text: Tom! East waves frantically to Tom, indicates the weir. The noise of the crashing weir is terrible. Tom starts to kick his legs hard, dragging Tadpole across current to where East waits, fingers extended. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tom Brown's Schooldays - Shooting Script 06.04.04 36A.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Tom’s fingers find East’s and the three boys drag themsel onto the bank, gasping for air.

dialogues.speaker: CUT TO
dialogues.text: 40 Tom Brown's Schooldays - Shooting Script 06.04.04 37. INT - RUGBY SCHOOL/ARNOLD’S STUDY - NIGHT 40 The corridor is dark, leading to a slither of light aroun Arnold’s study door. Tom, East and Tadpole huddle nervously together, cold, ti wet. They speak in whispers, the fear in their voices obvious.

dialogues.speaker: EAST
dialogues.text: What will we tell him?

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: The truth. That’s what he wants to hear, remember. Tom leads them up to the door and knocks on it.

dialogues.speaker: ARNOLD
dialogues.text: Come! Tom pushes the door open and there is Doctor Arnold, in h shirtsleeves, sat on the floor making a giant sail-boat w youngest children. Mary is in her chair making a tapestry. Spot the dog barks. Tom, East and Tadpole are surprised by this glimpse of th Doctor’s happy domestic life.

dialogues.speaker: ARNOLD
dialogues.text: Well, well, what a pretty sight. (To Mary) A moment, my dear. Mary rounds the curious children up and leaves the room.

dialogues.speaker: ARNOLD
dialogues.text: We meet again, Mr Brown. Perhaps you’d care to explain why you are so late?

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: Yes, sir. We were out on the Hare-and- hounds run and we lost our way and the harder we tried to find it the more lost we became.

dialogues.speaker: ARNOLD
dialogues.text: Aren’t you a little young to be on such a run? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 40 4l Tom Brown's Schooldays - Shooting Script 06.04.04 38.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Tadpole glares at Tom.

dialogues.speaker: TADPOLE
dialogues.text: Yes, sir.

dialogues.speaker: EAST
dialogues.text: We wanted to show the older boys what we could do, sir.

dialogues.speaker: ARNOLD
dialogues.text: Look at the state of you. Have you eaten?

dialogues.speaker: TADPOLE
dialogues.text: No, sir.

dialogues.speaker: ARNOLD
dialogues.text: Then get to your dorm and get clean clothes on and tell Matron I said you are to have some tea. The three boys are amazed at the Doctor’s leniency. The Doctor waves them out of his study. Hardly believing their luck, the boys hurry towards the d

dialogues.speaker: ARNOLD
dialogues.text: Brown. Tom turns at the sound of his name being called.

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: Yes, sir.

dialogues.speaker: ARNOLD
dialogues.text: Don’t let me see you again for a while, there’s a good fellow. Both boy and man know exactly what he means.

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: No, sir.

dialogues.speaker: CUT TO
dialogues.text: INT - RUGBY SCHOOL/FLASHMAN’S STUDY - NIGHT 4l Flashman’s study feels more like a gentleman’s club as he in a silk robe, sipping a fine claret and flipping throug nineteenth century porn. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 4l Tom Brown's Schooldays - Shooting Script 06.04.04 38A.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: He is wearing an ornate set of knuckledusters, absently p them into his other palm as he talks. Speedicot is drying some of Flashman’s clothes by the fir (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 4l Tom Brown's Schooldays - Shooting Script 06.04.04 39.

dialogues.speaker: FLASHMAN
dialogues.text: I nearly had her pendulous breasts trembling in the fresh air when that little Tadpole bastard ruined everything.

dialogues.speaker: SPEEDICOT
dialogues.text: East put him up to it, I’1l be bound.

dialogues.speaker: FLASHMAN
dialogues.text: Actually, I think it was that Brown fellow. He needs to be taken down a peg or two. There is a knock at the door.

dialogues.speaker: FLASHMAN
dialogues.text: Go away!

dialogues.speaker: SPEEDICOT
dialogues.text: Who is it?

dialogues.speaker: ARNOLD
dialogues.text: (Out Of Vision) The Doctor. Speedicot looks horrified.

dialogues.speaker: SPEEDICOT
dialogues.text: One moment, sir. Speedicot runs around the study hiding porn, alcohol, tob etc as Flashman looks on with an amused smile. Speedicot opens the door to Doctor Arnold.

dialogues.speaker: SPEEDICOT
dialogues.text: Sorry, sir. Deep in our books, don’t you know. I was just saying to Flashman -

dialogues.speaker: ARNOLD
dialogues.text: Leave us, Speedicot.

dialogues.speaker: SPEEDICOT
dialogues.text: (Delighted) Yes, sir! Speedicot hurries off down the corridor as Arnold closes study door behind him.

dialogues.speaker: ARNOLD
dialogues.text: Stand up when I come into the room. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tom Brown's Schooldays - Shooting Script 06.04.04 39A.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Flashman stands up wearily. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 4l Tom Brown's Schooldays - Shooting Script 06.04.04 40.

dialogues.speaker: ARNOLD
dialogues.text: Where were you this afternoon?

dialogues.speaker: FLASHMAN
dialogues.text: This afternoon, sir? I believe I went for a walk.

dialogues.speaker: ARNOLD
dialogues.text: By the river, I understand. Flashman’s eyes narrow at this.

dialogues.speaker: FLASHMAN
dialogues.text: I'd be very alarmed, sir, if I thought you were taking the word of three impudent young fellows against -

dialogues.speaker: ARNOLD
dialogues.text: What fellows? What are you talking about? Flashman is thrown for a moment.

dialogues.speaker: ARNOLD
dialogues.text: A very serious allegation has been made against you by a young lady.

dialogues.speaker: FLASHMAN
dialogues.text: A young lady, sir?

dialogues.speaker: ARNOLD
dialogues.text: Sally Hopkins.

dialogues.speaker: FLASHMAN
dialogues.text: Oh, the matron’s daughter. One could quibble with your definition of a “lady”.

dialogues.speaker: ARNOLD
dialogues.text: She says you tried to seduce her. To force yourself on her.

dialogues.speaker: FLASHMAN
dialogues.text: The truth is, sir, that when one’s father has a large fortune it tends to drive a woman of a certain sort to distraction. Arnold looks hard at Flashman.

dialogues.speaker: ARNOLD
dialogues.text: You are denying the allegation? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tom Brown's Schooldays - Shooting Script 06.04.04 40A.

dialogues.speaker: FLASHMAN
dialogues.text: Of course I am, sir. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Tom Brown's Schooldays - Shooting Script 06.04.04 41. (6) Al

dialogues.speaker: ARNOLD
dialogues.text: You give me your word?

dialogues.speaker: FLASHMAN
dialogues.text: Absolutely. Arnold realises that there is nowhere for this conversati go. A beat as

dialogues.speaker: ARNOLD
dialogues.text: I hear things, Mr Flashman.

dialogues.speaker: FLASHMAN
dialogues.text: (Cheeky ) Like voices, sir?

dialogues.speaker: ARNOLD
dialogues.text: I will rip the bad apples out of this school, I don’t care who they are.

dialogues.speaker: FLASHMAN
dialogues.text: Good for you, sir. You’ll certainly have my full support. the two men look at each other.

dialogues.speaker: ARNOLD
dialogues.text: Good evening.

dialogues.speaker: FLASHMAN
dialogues.text: Good night, sir. Arnold turns and leaves a grinning Flashman on his own in study. He recovers his glass of wine, takes a deep draught of it

dialogues.speaker: CUT TO
dialogues.text: INT - RUGBY SCHOOL/ARNOLD’S STUDY - DAY 42 Arnold is having a tense conversation with Smith and Lamp

dialogues.speaker: SMITH
dialogues.text: He’s a vain, vicious, nasty piece of work, Headmaster, with a list of indiscretions and crimes as long as your arm.

dialogues.speaker: ARNOLD
dialogues.text: Then what is he still doing here? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tom Brown's Schooldays - Shooting Script 06.04.04 42.

dialogues.speaker: LAMPARD
dialogues.text: You know who his father is, of course?

dialogues.speaker: ARNOLD
dialogues.text: I understand he’s a generous benefactor of the school.

dialogues.speaker: LAMPARD
dialogues.text: Without his money this place would have collapsed years ago. There have been bullies before him, there will be bullies after him -

dialogues.speaker: ARNOLD
dialogues.text: (Angry) Not in my school there won't. Smith looks at Arnold, is slowly warming to him.

dialogues.speaker: SMITH
dialogues.text: It would indeed send out a serious message about bullying if Flashman was sent down. Lampard looks to the Heavens.

dialogues.speaker: LAMPARD
dialogues.text: It’s not my place to offer advice, Headmaster...

dialogues.speaker: ARNOLD
dialogues.text: Go on, Mr Lampard.

dialogues.speaker: LAMPARD
dialogues.text: Don’t even think of expelling Flashman. If you force the Trustees to choose between you and his father’s resources... Lampard doesn’t have to finish the sentence.

dialogues.speaker: EXT
dialogues.text: A cloud passes over the large yellow moon above Rugby Sch

dialogues.speaker: CUT TO
dialogues.text: 44 45 46 Tom Brown's Schooldays - Shooting Script 06.04.04 43. INT - RUGBY SCHOOL/TOM’S STUDY - NIGHT 44 Unlike Flashman's study, Tom and East’s is a chaos of boo broken cricket bats; pictures of Victorian boxers; candle wax; cups; bottles etc East and Tom pretend to read but their minds are elsewher listening for the call that will surely come. It does:

dialogues.speaker: FLASHMAN
dialogues.text: (Out Of Vision) Faaaaag! East and Tom look at each other, know this is the moment.

dialogues.speaker: CUT TO
dialogues.text: INT - RUGBY SCHOOL/FLASHMAN’S STUDY - NIGHT 45 Flashman is at his door, leaning out into the corridor.

dialogues.speaker: FLASHMAN
dialogues.text: Faaaaaag! Still nothing.

dialogues.speaker: FLASHMAN
dialogues.text: East! Brown! Come here, you cursed shirkers!

dialogues.speaker: CUT TO

dialogues.text: (Out Of Vision) Faaaaaag! Tom and East leap up and start barricading themselves in, locking the door, sliding the bolts over. They hear Flashman’s voice right outside the door.

dialogues.speaker: FLASHMAN
dialogues.text: Open the door, little piggies. Tom and East look at each other, scared but determined. Then there is a thump, thump as shoulders charge the old door. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.text: 46 Tom Brown's Schooldays - Shooting Script 06.04.04 44.

dialogues.text: Then one of the panels splinters as an axe bursts through East and Tom back away. Again and again the axe shatters through the old wood unt of the panels is ripped asunder. Flashman’s face appears in the hole, drunk and crazed.

dialogues.speaker: FLASHMAN
dialogues.text: It’s Flashy. Tom and East take their sofa and ram it against the door.

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: We're not fagging for you, Flashman! Another beat, the silence worse than noise for Tom and Ea Then balls of flaming paper are thrown through the hole i door, filling the little study with smoke. Tom and East struggle to put them out but there is smoke sparks everywhere. Their eyes are smarting, their lungs screaming, near defe

dialogues.speaker: FROBISHER
dialogues.text: (Out Of Vision) What in God’s name is happening here?! East and Tom open the window, gulp in the fresh air.

dialogues.speaker: FROBISHER
dialogues.text: (Out Of Vision) Open the door, Brown! Tom and East unbolt the door and open it. Flashman glares in at them, standing next to Speedicot an others of the Fifth.

dialogues.speaker: FROBISHER
dialogues.text: (To Flashman) You could have burnt the school down, you idiot.

dialogues.speaker: FLASHMAN
dialogues.text: They were being impudent.

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: We're not going to fag for the Fifth any more. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 46 47 Tom Brown's Schooldays - Shooting Script 06.04.04 45.

dialogues.speaker: FLASHMAN
dialogues.text: You see what we have to put up with? They’re dragging the House down with their lack of respect. Frobisher is torn between doing what is right and wanting popular with the older boys.

dialogues.speaker: EAST
dialogues.text: Brooke said we didn’t have to fag for the Fifth. Frobisher knows this is true and can’t go against the mem Brooke.

dialogues.speaker: FROBISHER
dialogues.text: He’s right. Now cut along, Flashman, and no more fagging until you’re in the Sixth. Flashman just smiles his smile.

dialogues.speaker: FLASHMAN
dialogues.text: Yes, Frobisher. Flashman, Speedicot and the others slink back to their st

dialogues.speaker: FROBISHER
dialogues.text: (To East and Tom) You two clean that mess up. Frobisher moves off, leaving Tom and East to grin at each

dialogues.speaker: INT
dialogues.text: The entire school is gathering for morning service, yawni fighting, watched over by Frobisher and the other Prefect Flashman, Fothergill and Speedicot try and look above it Tom and East arrive late and scruffy, as usual. As they come into the chapel an extraordinary thing happe some of the smallest boys start to applaud. It’s only a r at first but it quickly spreads, until most of the school cheering and stamping.

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: Who are they cheering? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 47 48 49 Tom Brown's Schooldays - Shooting Script 06.04.04 46.

dialogues.speaker: EAST
dialogues.text: Us, you fool. Tom is highly amused by this, waves royally. He has never experienced such adulation before and it goes immediately head. East, on the other hand, glances up at Flashman with real knows this isn’t the end of it.

dialogues.speaker: FROBISHER
dialogues.text: Silence! Silence! The cheers die down but Tom has had his first taste of re popularity and he likes it. He really likes it.

dialogues.speaker: EXT
dialogues.text: It’s winter and the school buildings are glowering in the light.

dialogues.speaker: EXT
dialogues.text: A quiet day, just a few fat chickens pecking around a far Suddenly Tom and East pounce on the chickens and there is explosion of cluckings and feathers.

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: Got one! Tom struggles with the chicken. The door of the farm house crashes open and an irate FARM bursts out, an ancient blunderbuss in his hands.

dialogues.speaker: EAST
dialogues.text: Tom! Tom clutches onto his prize and the two boys run off acro fields to freedom. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 49 50 51 Tom Brown's Schooldays - Shooting Script 06.04.04 47.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: The Farmer unloads his blunderbuss into the sky but the b keep running.

dialogues.text: The school house is full of boys being taught by differen Masters in different parts of the room. Tom and East are struggling to pronounce their Greek as t chant with their colleagues. Suddenly everyone stands and Tom looks around: Doctor Arnold has come into the School House and he is no alone. The Farmer is with him. Tom and East freeze in horror. Arnold looks very stern, v angry. Arnold walks through the School Room with the Farmer, the looking at every boy in turn with fierce concentration. He looks hard at East. But he’s obviously not convinced a about to move on when he catches Tom’s face. The Farmer recognises Tom and he points a finger at him.

dialogues.speaker: FARMER
dialogues.text: That be the one what stole it. * Arnold looks at Tom who looks bravely back at him.

dialogues.speaker: ARNOLD
dialogues.text: Go to my study, Brown.

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: Yes, sir. Tom walks out of the School House, all eyes on him, his footsteps the only sound in the echoing hall. Arnold looks at East but says nothing.

dialogues.speaker: CUT TO

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A nervous Tom stands in front of Arnold in the silence of study. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tom Brown's Schooldays - Shooting Script 06.04.04 48.

dialogues.speaker: ARNOLD
dialogues.text: Who was your accomplice in this crime?

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: No-one, sir.

dialogues.speaker: ARNOLD
dialogues.text: The farmer says there were two of you.

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: Just me, sir. Tom says nothing.

dialogues.speaker: ARNOLD
dialogues.text: You stole from this man, Brown. Would you care to explain why?

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: Not really stole, sir.

dialogues.speaker: ARNOLD
dialogues.text: The chicken belonged to you, did it?

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: No, sir.

dialogues.speaker: ARNOLD
dialogues.text: Then in what way was it not stealing?

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: It’s a prank, sir. We've always liberated the odd chicken or two, sir, it’s a Rugby tradition. Arnold looks at the boy, feels his anger rising.

dialogues.speaker: ARNOLD
dialogues.text: A Rugby tradition?

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: Yes, sir.

dialogues.speaker: ARNOLD
dialogues.text: You dare stand in front of me and say that stealing is a tradition? Tom says nothing, realises he’s played this completely th way. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 51 52 53 54 Tom Brown's Schooldays - Shooting Script 06.04.04 49.

dialogues.speaker: ARNOLD
dialogues.text: Then it’s a tradition I'd best beat out of you, isn’t? Go to the tower and wait for me. Tom leaves the room.

dialogues.text: Tom Brown walks up the lonely spiral stairs of the caning He pushes a door open and there is a wooden caning stool. Tom leans over the stool, his buttocks raised, awaits his

dialogues.speaker: EXT
dialogues.text: A gaggle of boys - including East, Tadpole and Green - ga and watch Arnold walk slowly across the quad towards the tower.

dialogues.speaker: TADPOLE
dialogues.text: He’s dead. Died for a chicken.

dialogues.text: Tom waits. Far below he hears the door of the tower open and close. Arnold’s footsteps ring out as he slowly ascends the spir stair case. Tom breathes heavier, frightened now but determined to be strong. The door of the room opens and Arnold steps in. He selects a cane from the selection. Swishes it. A beat. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 54 55 Tom Brown's Schooldays - Shooting Script 06.04.04 50.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Arnold doesn’t want to do this but knows he has to, movin quickly from regret to resolve. He raises the cane and hi hard. * Tom’s eyes water with pain and anger and humiliation as t continues to whip down. *

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All the boys, from the smallest to the largest, are gathe the school house for a riotous night of drinking and reve Tom is the centre of attention, chewing on a chicken wing to East. Tom is a real product of old Rugby now, scruffy bolshy. In The background a small, timid new boy - WESTON - is tr sing his song, the candles burning his hands, being pelte the other boys. FROBISHER, HUBAND and several other members of the Sixth in, serious-faced but barely noticed in the mayhem. Weston falters, in tears, and is made to drink the salt w loud cheers.

dialogues.speaker: FROBISHER
dialogues.text: Silence! Silence in here! The other Prefects smash their sticks down for the silenc finally arrives.

dialogues.speaker: FROBISHER
dialogues.text: This afternoon I had a discussion with the Doctor when he made plain his displeasure with School House -

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: What about my displeasure with him! Tom shows his buttocks to much hilarity.

dialogues.speaker: FROBISHER
dialogues.text: - and he informed me that from now on all his reforms must be met without further obstruction. There will be no more gambling in School House. Boos from the boys. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tom Brown's Schooldays - Shooting Script 06.04.04 50A.

dialogues.speaker: FROBISHER
dialogues.text: Any boy found gambling will be reported to me and thrashed. After that he will go straight to the Doctor. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 55 Tom Brown's Schooldays - Shooting Script 06.04.04 51.

dialogues.speaker: EAST
dialogues.text: Shame! Tom and East’s set is starting to get rowdy, fuelled by b The Prefects call for silence again.

dialogues.speaker: FROBISHER
dialogues.text: There will be no more drinking of any sort. Any boy found distilling or brewing alcohol will be instantly sent down by the Doctor. The boys start to murmur with discontent.

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: Can’t we just wait until Christmas when the Doctor will be sent down by the trustees anyway? Much cheering and laughter.

dialogues.speaker: FROBISHER
dialogues.text: I’d ask you not to forget who you’re talking about, Brown.

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: The man who is destroying this school, Frobisher. More loud cheers.

dialogues.speaker: FROBISHER
dialogues.text: (Furious, to his Prefects) Get him out. The Prefects wade in to remove Tom from the assembly but friends pull him back. There is an ugly little scrummage, a few punches are thro few canes swished down on young limbs.

dialogues.speaker: FROBISHER
dialogues.text: Stop this! Stop this at once! Mayhem in the old School House. Flashman watches all this, fascinated, not sure which way turn. He looks over at Frobisher, who looks really worrie

dialogues.speaker: FLASHMAN
dialogues.text: Permission to help out, Frobisher? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tom Brown's Schooldays - Shooting Script 06.04.04 51A.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Frobisher nods. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: 56B
dialogues.text: 57 Tom Brown's Schooldays - Shooting Script 06.04.04 52.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Flashman - with Speedicot, Fothergill and others of the F behind him - lays into the smaller boys with his cane. A window is broken. A boy screams out, trampled.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Boys fight running battles in the corridors, rioting, ble yelling.

dialogues.speaker: CUT TO

dialogues.text: Arnold is sleeping next to Mary when the sound of the bar dog wakes them.

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: What is it? Something crashes over at the school followed by cheers. Arnold hurriedly gets out of bed.

dialogues.speaker: CUT TO
dialogues.text: INT - RUGBY SCHOOL/ARNOLD’S HOUSE/CORRIDOR/WINDOW - NIGHT

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Arnold looks out of the window and what he sees chills hi shocks him:

dialogues.speaker: EXT
dialogues.text: Windows burst open as objects are thrown from the school crash to the ground below. The retreated Frobisher, Huband and some of the prefects with dismay. Then Frobisher rallies his troops:

dialogues.speaker: FROBISHER
dialogues.text: Come on! We must restore order! Frobisher starts towards the rioting school but realises others are hanging back. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Tom Brown's Schooldays - Shooting Script 06.04.04

dialogues.speaker: FROBISHER
dialogues.text: Come on! 57 52A.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Reluctantly Huband and the others run towards the school Frobisher. INT - RUGBY SCHOOL/ARNOLD’S STUDY - NIGHT A furious Arnold paces the floor of his study.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Frobisher stands before him, nervous, shocked, his face c bruised from the struggle.

dialogues.speaker: ARNOLD
dialogues.text: It is under control?

dialogues.speaker: FROBISHER
dialogues.text: Yes, sir.

dialogues.speaker: ARNOLD
dialogues.text: I will not stand for it. If you cannot control the boys in your own House then I will.

dialogues.speaker: FROBISHER
dialogues.text: I can do it, sir.

dialogues.speaker: ARNOLD
dialogues.text: Who was the ringleader?

dialogues.speaker: FROBISHER
dialogues.text: Hard to say, sir. As you know some of your reforms are universally disliked by the - (CONTINUED)

dialogues.text: 58 59 60 Tom Brown's Schooldays - Shooting Script 06.04.04 53.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Arnold smashes his hand down on his desk making Frobisher

dialogues.speaker: ARNOLD
dialogues.text: (Furious) Who was it?!

dialogues.speaker: FROBISHER
dialogues.text: Brown was a little more vocal than some of the others, Headmaster.

dialogues.speaker: ARNOLD
dialogues.text: If there is a repeat of this shameful behaviour I will remove you from your position as Captain of School House. Is that clear?

dialogues.speaker: FROBISHER
dialogues.text: Yes, sir.

dialogues.speaker: INT
dialogues.text: Tom walks into the great School House. At the far end Frobisher waits for him, his cane in hand, otherwise the place is deserted. Tom walks cockily towards him.

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: Morning, Frobisher. Without being asked, Tom spreads himself on the prefect’s and awaits his punishment.

dialogues.speaker: INT
dialogues.text: Arnold walks sternly down the corridor that leads to the House, opens the doors. Tom and East are slumped at their desks, Tom carving his and East making crude drawings of football matches. They stop as they see the Doctor come into the room. FOTHERGILL is sitting up at the raised Master’s desk and a cheap novel. All the boys stand up as they see Arnold. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 60 Tom Brown's Schooldays - Shooting Script 06.04.04 54.

dialogues.speaker: ARNOLD
dialogues.text: Sit down, gentlemen.

dialogues.speaker: FOTHERGILL
dialogues.text: (Nervous ) Mr Smith is unwell, sir. I’m taking the Third for Greek.

dialogues.speaker: ARNOLD
dialogues.text: I know he is unwell, I have just come from his house. He turns to the boys, eyes finally alighting on Tadpole.

dialogues.speaker: ARNOLD
dialogues.text: (To Tadpole) Hall. Tadpole leaps to his feet.

dialogues.speaker: TADPOLE
dialogues.text: Sir?

dialogues.speaker: ARNOLD
dialogues.text: I believe you have a passage of Xenophon you have prepared. Read it to me. Tadpole starts to stagger badly through the passage.

dialogues.speaker: ARNOLD
dialogues.text: Stop. Tadpole stops, hopes this is the end of it.

dialogues.speaker: ARNOLD
dialogues.text: That is not the passage you are meant to have prepared. This is the passage. Arnold skips further on in Tadpole’s book, points.

dialogues.speaker: TADPOLE
dialogues.text: Begging your pardon, sir, but we were not asked to prepare that far, sir. Arnold scowls at him.

dialogues.speaker: ARNOLD
dialogues.text: You think Mr Smith and I are mistaken?

dialogues.speaker: TADPOLE
dialogues.text: Sir. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tom Brown's Schooldays - Shooting Script 06.04.04 55.

dialogues.speaker: ARNOLD
dialogues.text: Then I shall consult the note that Mr Smith wrote for me just twenty minutes ago. There is tension in the air as Arnold takes the note from pocket and reads.

dialogues.speaker: ARNOLD
dialogues.text: You are the one who is mistaken.

dialogues.speaker: TADPOLE
dialogues.text: Begging your pardon, sir, I am not mistaken, sir. We have all prepared -

dialogues.speaker: ARNOLD
dialogues.text: You dare contradict me? Silence.

dialogues.speaker: ARNOLD
dialogues.text: Are you saying that Mr Smith’s note is erroneous?

dialogues.speaker: TADPOLE
dialogues.text: (Puzzled) Sir?

dialogues.speaker: ARNOLD
dialogues.text: Is the note mistaken?

dialogues.speaker: TADPOLE
dialogues.text: Yes, sir. Arnold turns to Green.

dialogues.speaker: ARNOLD
dialogues.text: Green. Green jumps to his feet.

dialogues.speaker: ARNOLD
dialogues.text: Run to Mr Smith’s house with this note and my apologies. Ask him if he could possibly have made a mistake. Green takes the note and hurries out of the School Room. Arnold turns to look at the shaking Tadpole. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tom Brown's Schooldays - Shooting Script 06.04.04 55A.

dialogues.speaker: ARNOLD
dialogues.text: If I find out that you have been lying to me I will flog you, sir, to within an inch of your life. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 60 61 62 63 64 Tom Brown's Schooldays - Shooting Script 06.04.04 56.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Tadpole just stares ahead, close to tears. Tom hates seeing his friend suffer, stands up.

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: Sir -

dialogues.speaker: ARNOLD
dialogues.text: Sit down, Brown! Tom sits back down.

dialogues.speaker: EXT
dialogues.text: Green flies across the playing field of the school.

dialogues.speaker: EXT
dialogues.text: Green sprints up the steps of a house and rings the bell. The door opens and Green is admitted.

dialogues.speaker: INT
dialogues.text: Arnold walks slowly up and down the aisle of the School H the atmosphere incredibly tense. Tadpole stands, a picture of misery. Tom watches Arnold and there is a moment when the man’s e meet the boy’s in a battle of will.

dialogues.speaker: EXT
dialogues.text: Green runs back across the playing fields, breathing heav

dialogues.speaker: CUT TO
dialogues.text: Tom Brown's Schooldays - Shooting Script 06.04.04 56A.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The atmosphere is still tense in the School Room when Gre enters. All eyes look to him. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 65 66 Tom Brown's Schooldays - Shooting Script 06.04.04 57.

dialogues.speaker: GREEN
dialogues.text: Mr Smith says the note is correct. There is an audible intake of breath and now all eyes tur the unfortunate Tadpole.

dialogues.speaker: ARNOLD
dialogues.text: (To Tadpole) Stand up. Tadpole gets slowly to his feet.

dialogues.speaker: ARNOLD
dialogues.text: You have lied to me.

dialogues.speaker: TADPOLE
dialogues.text: No, sir.

dialogues.speaker: ARNOLD
dialogues.text: (Losing it) Liar! Liar! Liar! Arnold’s words echo around the room, chilling the blood o boys.

dialogues.speaker: ARNOLD
dialogues.text: Put your left hand out. Tadpole does as he is told, his hand shaking with fear. Arnold takes out a cane, swishes it.

dialogues.speaker: ARNOLD
dialogues.text: (Quiet) You will never lie to me again. Tadpole is crying before the first blow slashes across hi Another. Another. Arnold seems to be in the clutches of a terrible, white-hot anger. Six strokes. The boys expect him to stop here but he keep going. East and Tom exchange an appalled look.

dialogues.speaker: EXT
dialogues.text: As the sound of the cane whips down on Tadpole’s hand we dissolving run of images: (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 66 67 68 Tom Brown's Schooldays - Shooting Script 06.04.04 58.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: An empty corridor. An empty dorm. An empty study.

dialogues.speaker: INT
dialogues.text: Only when the eighteenth stroke has lashed Tadpole’s hand Arnold stop. Arnold puts his hand out to be shaken and Tadpole shakes his right hand.

dialogues.speaker: TADPOLE
dialogues.text: Thank you, sir. Arnold then turns to the boys.

dialogues.speaker: ARNOLD
dialogues.text: I believe a boy’s word as I would believe a man’s. This is what it means. Arnold walks out of the School Room and the boys rise to feet. Tom watches Arnold leave with a mixture of contempt and f

dialogues.speaker: CUT TO
dialogues.text: INT - RUGBY SCHOOL/ARNOLD’S HOUSE/DINING ROOM - NIGHT 68 The Arnold Family are dining, the atmosphere very quiet, clinking on china. Mary looks over at Arnold, knows he is upset at what has happened.

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: One day, my dear, that boy will meet you again as a man and thank you for what you did today. Arnold looks at his hand. It is still shaking.

dialogues.speaker: ARNOLD
dialogues.text: I thought if I treated them like equals they would respond as equals. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tom Brown's Schooldays - Shooting Script 06.04.04 58A.

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: They will, given time. Now they still think all Masters are the enemy to be lied to and tricked. (MORE ) (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 68 69 Tom Brown's Schooldays - Shooting Script 06.04.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: MARY (cont'd) When they know that what you do you do out of love -

dialogues.speaker: ARNOLD
dialogues.text: Love? It was anger, not love. The door opens and Sally bustles in.

dialogues.speaker: SALLY
dialogues.text: Begging your pardon, Doctor, but he wouldn’t take no for an answer. 04 59. 68 Before Arnold can answer the question a very ill-looking comes into the room.

dialogues.speaker: ARNOLD
dialogues.text: Mr Smith. What on earth are you doing out of bed?

dialogues.speaker: SMITH
dialogues.text: (Agitated) I heard what happened.

dialogues.speaker: ARNOLD
dialogues.text: It’s over now. The boy lied to me and I have dealt with it. Now get yourself back to -

dialogues.speaker: SMITH
dialogues.text: When the boy arrived at my house I was half delirious with fever. I was annoyed that you would call on me when you knew I was unwell.

dialogues.speaker: ARNOLD
dialogues.text: It was important.

dialogues.speaker: SMITH
dialogues.text: I didn’t look at the note correctly. Hall was right, he prepared the correct passage.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 69 Tadpole lies face down on his bed, tears still streaming his eyes as he hiccups with sobs. The other boys lie on their beds, listening. Even Huband feels for Tadpole. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tom Brown's Schooldays - Shooting Script 06.04.04 59A.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: There is a knock at the door. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 69 Tom Brown's Schooldays - Shooting Script 06.04.04 60.

dialogues.speaker: HUBAND
dialogues.text: Come! The door opens and Arnold appears in the dormitory. The boys are amazed and frightened, stand up straight by beds. Arnold walks towards Tadpole who involuntarily flinches.

dialogues.speaker: ARNOLD
dialogues.text: I just had a discussion with Mr Smith and it does indeed appear that you were in the right and I was in the wrong. The boys look at each other, very surprised at this devel

dialogues.speaker: ARNOLD
dialogues.text: I have written to your parents and apologised to them for what happened today. If you want to leave school in the morning and take a coach home I will understand.

dialogues.speaker: TADPOLE
dialogues.text: (Alarmed) Sir?

dialogues.speaker: ARNOLD
dialogues.text: Personally, I very much hope you will remain at Rugby School and that we will both learn from this day and move on together.

dialogues.speaker: TADPOLE
dialogues.text: Yes, sir.

dialogues.speaker: ARNOLD
dialogues.text: It only remains for me to hope you will accept my sincere apologies. Arnold puts his hand out to the astonished Tadpole. Tadpole shakes his Headmaster’s hand.

dialogues.speaker: ARNOLD
dialogues.text: Thank you, Hall. Arnold looks around at Tom and the other boys.

dialogues.speaker: ARNOLD
dialogues.text: Good night, gentlemen. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 69 70 Tom Brown's Schooldays - Shooting Script 06.04.04 61.
