dialogues.text: There is a bustle of interest in the School Room as all t in the House draw sweepstake lots from Speedicot’s hat as Flashman looks on. Other members of the Fifth lounge languidly around, looki betting sheets. A large fire crackles in the great fireplace. Tom and East are in line with the others.

dialogues.speaker: SPEEDICOT
dialogues.text: Roll up, roll up! Get your ticket for the Derby here! Tadpole, you’re next. Tadpole takes out a ticket and lets Speedicot read it.

dialogues.speaker: SPEEDICOT
dialogues.text: “The Wanderer”! Tadpole’s drawn the third favourite. Flashman takes an immediate interest in this.

dialogues.speaker: FLASHMAN
dialogues.text: What’11 you sell him for?

dialogues.speaker: TADPOLE
dialogues.text: I don’t want to sell.

dialogues.speaker: FLASHMAN
dialogues.text: He won’t win but I want him as a hedge. I’1l give you half-a-crown for him.

dialogues.speaker: TADPOLE
dialogues.text: No. Flashman just leans in to Tadpole’s face.

dialogues.speaker: FLASHMAN
dialogues.text: (Quiet) I’m not the Doctor. I won’t apologise after I’ve beaten you. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tom Brown's Schooldays - Shooting Script 06.04.04 61A.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Tadpole knows he’s beaten, puts out his hand for the coin (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 70 Tom Brown's Schooldays - Shooting Script 06.04.04 62.

dialogues.speaker: FLASHMAN
dialogues.text: I’ll pay you later. Next! Tadpole slinks off, dejected.

dialogues.speaker: SPEEDICOT
dialogues.text: Next. Brown. Tom pulls out his ticket which Speedicot reads.

dialogues.speaker: SPEEDICOT
dialogues.text: “Harkaway”! Your little chum’s pulled out the favourite, Flashy.

dialogues.speaker: FLASHMAN
dialogues.text: Give it to me. Tom is quick and grabs the ticket back.

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: Get your own, Flashman.

dialogues.speaker: FLASHMAN
dialogues.text: You’1l sell it to me, Brown.

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: I will not.

dialogues.speaker: FLASHMAN
dialogues.text: What have I always said? The cockiest blackguard in the House. Flashman surveys the boys left in the School House.

dialogues.speaker: FLASHMAN
dialogues.text: You boys! Out. Now. The boys are more than happy to escape Flashman and the o members of the Fifth. Tom is about to leave with East but Flashman steps in fro them.

dialogues.speaker: FLASHMAN
dialogues.text: Not you, Brown.

dialogues.speaker: EAST
dialogues.text: Leave him alone, Flashman. A nod from Flashman and several members of the Fifth grab and throw him out of the School House and shut the door. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tom Brown's Schooldays - Shooting Script 06.04.04 62A.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Now only Tom is left with Flashman, Speedicot, Fothergill the Fifth. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 70 Tom Brown's Schooldays - Shooting Script 06.04.04 63.

dialogues.speaker: FLASHMAN
dialogues.text: I will ask you one more time. Give me the ticket.

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: I will not. Flashman smiles.

dialogues.speaker: FLASHMAN
dialogues.text: Good. Because I’ve been looking forward to this for some time. Tom is puzzled, knows something is about to happen.

dialogues.speaker: FLASHMAN
dialogues.text: Roast him! A roar goes up from the Fifth and they manhandle Tom over fireplace. Tom’s wrists are held against the mantelpiece and his leg spread-eagled. The heat is obviously intense and Tom’s face starts to cr with pain.

dialogues.speaker: SPEEDICOT
dialogues.text: Best sell us the ticket, Brown. Tom shakes his head.

dialogues.speaker: FLASHMAN
dialogues.text: Damn the ticket. I want him to burn. Tom struggles but Flashman is determined to keep him ther Tom’s clothes start to smoke.

dialogues.speaker: SPEEDICOT
dialogues.text: (Getting concerned) I say, Flashy, I think he’s had enough.

dialogues.speaker: FLASHMAN
dialogues.text: Nonsense. You haven’t had enough, have you, Brown? Flashman takes Tom’s sagging head by his hair and makes T shake his head.

dialogues.speaker: FLASHMAN
dialogues.text: There, you see? Let’s roast his front! (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 70 71 72 Tom Brown's Schooldays - Shooting Script 06.04.04 64.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: They go to turn Tom around and see with horror that his c are nearly burned right off, that his flesh is red and se The Fifth drop Tom, let him crumple to the floor, as they their escape.

dialogues.speaker: PART FIVE
dialogues.text: INT - RUGBY SCHOOL/MATRON’S SICK ROOM - NIGHT 71 Tom lies face down as a NURSE administers to his burnt fl

dialogues.speaker: CUT TO
dialogues.text: INT - RUGBY SCHOOL/ARNOLD’S HOUSE/BEDROOM - NIGHT 72 Mary lies cradled in the crook of her husband's arm, both them wide awake.

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: How can they be so cruel to each other?

dialogues.speaker: ARNOLD
dialogues.text: This has been a dark place for far too long and one cannot change it ina trice.

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: And their stupid loyalty to each other. How can you help them if they don’t help themselves? A beat.

dialogues.speaker: ARNOLD
dialogues.text: I fear I’ve let young Brown down.

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: Never.

dialogues.speaker: ARNOLD
dialogues.text: A bright boy like that. Brave and full of spirit. (MORE ) (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tom Brown's Schooldays - Shooting Script 06.04.04 64A.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: ARNOLD (cont'd) And what has Rugby done to him? Turned him into an agitator, a thief. (MORE ) (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 72 73 Tom Brown's Schooldays - Shooting Script 06.04.04 65.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: ARNOLD (cont'd) Lying on his stomach with his back half burnt from his body. Arnold is upset, angry with himself.

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: You’ve always liked him, haven’t you?

dialogues.speaker: ARNOLD
dialogues.text: I’m going to ask his father to take him out of the school.

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: Why?

dialogues.speaker: ARNOLD
dialogues.text: Because this place has poisoned him and the poison must be cut out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: East and Tom are stuffing the last of their belongings in their bags..

dialogues.speaker: EAST
dialogues.text: Try and behave yourself in dull old Berkshire. Weston runs into the dorm.

dialogues.speaker: WESTON
dialogues.text: Brown, the Doctor wants to see you in his study straight away. Tom and East look at each other.

dialogues.speaker: EAST
dialogues.text: What have you done now?

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: Depends what he’s found out about. I’ll see you next term. The boys shake hands, incredibly good friends now, off to the Headmaster’s study with trepidation. and Tom heads

dialogues.speaker: CUT TO
dialogues.text: Tom Brown's Schooldays - Shooting Script 06.04.04 66. 74 INT - RUGBY SCHOOL/ARNOLD’S STUDY - DAY 74 Tom knocks on the open door of Arnold’s study and edges i

dialogues.speaker: ARNOLD
dialogues.text: Brown. I’d like you to give this to your father. Tom takes an envelope from Arnold.

dialogues.speaker: ARNOLD
dialogues.text: It’s a letter outlining your behaviour since you have been at Rugby School.

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: (Appalled) Am I being sent down, sir?

dialogues.speaker: ARNOLD
dialogues.text: Give the letter to your father.

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: Sir.

dialogues.speaker: EXT
dialogues.text: Tom sits thoughtfully atop the coach as it readies itself departure, the letter clutched in his nervous hand. The coach clatters away. Flashman looks out over the street, then pulls the curtai shut.

dialogues.speaker: INT
dialogues.text: In a room above a tavern Sally is admiring a ring Flashma given her.

dialogues.speaker: SALLY
dialogues.text: What did your parents say?

dialogues.speaker: FLASHMAN
dialogues.text: Their shouts of joy echoed around the estate. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tom Brown's Schooldays - Shooting Script 06.04.04 67.

dialogues.speaker: SALLY
dialogues.text: (Overwhelmed) Flashy.

dialogues.speaker: FLASHMAN
dialogues.text: So now am I entitled to my pound of flesh, wife-as—almost-is? Sally doesn’t understand the reference.

dialogues.speaker: FLASHMAN
dialogues.text: My reward, sweet girl.

dialogues.speaker: SALLY
dialogues.text: (Flirty) A kiss, you mean?

dialogues.speaker: FLASHMAN
dialogues.text: Sort of a kiss, yes. Put your hands on the bedstead.

dialogues.speaker: SALLY
dialogues.text: What for?

dialogues.speaker: FLASHMAN
dialogues.text: Just do it. Sally turns and does what she is told. Flashman lifts her skirt with his cane to reveal her butt

dialogues.speaker: FLASHMAN
dialogues.text: Oh my. Rather more than a pound. Flashman unbuttons his breeches.

dialogues.speaker: INT
dialogues.text: Squire Brown is finishing Arnold’s letter as Tom stands a looks on, nervous.

dialogues.speaker: SQUIRE
dialogues.text: Are you so very unhappy there that you behave like this?

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: No, father.

dialogues.speaker: SQUIRE
dialogues.text: Stealing, lying, fighting. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 77 78 Tom Brown's Schooldays - Shooting Script 06.04.04 68.

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: I don’t think Doctor Arnold likes me, father. He is bringing in such changes to the old place you'd barely recognise it. Why, only the other day -

dialogues.speaker: SQUIRE
dialogues.text: The only reason I sent you there was because I had hoped the Doctor would stop the rot in an institution I once loved very much. Now I read that you have fought him and his reforms at every stage. Tom says nothing.

dialogues.speaker: SQUIRE
dialogues.text: You say the Doctor does not like you? The Squire reads the letter out loud.

dialogues.speaker: SQUIRE
dialogues.text: “I believe your son has all the potential qualities that a Rugby man should have. Great courage; decency of instinct; fairness; thoughtfulness. I sincerely hope you feel it in your heart to send him back to us”. The Squire lets the Doctor’s words work on Tom.

dialogues.speaker: SQUIRE
dialogues.text: Last chance, Thomas.

dialogues.speaker: EXT
dialogues.text: Another term is about to start at Rugby School and there usual chaos of arriving coaches, boys, parents and luggag The rugby posts have gone and cricket stumps have been pu into the green turf. Arnold - with Spot at his side - walks across the playing fields, Lampard at his side. Arnold seems to have a new e and optimism on the first day of term. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 78 79 Tom Brown's Schooldays - Shooting Script 06.04.04 69.

dialogues.speaker: LAMPARD
dialogues.text: It is preposterous! You want me to live in the school? Actually, in the school?

dialogues.speaker: ARNOLD
dialogues.text: Actually in the school, yes.

dialogues.speaker: LAMPARD
dialogues.text: I am senior master here and I won’t do it! Is it not enough that I give the wretched boys my every waking hour as it is?

dialogues.speaker: ARNOLD
dialogues.text: No, Mr Lampard, it is not enough.

dialogues.speaker: LAMPARD
dialogues.text: Then I shall have no alternative than to hand in my resignation. An upper window in Arnold’s house opens and Mary leans ou

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: He’s here. Arnold nods, pleased.

dialogues.speaker: ARNOLD
dialogues.text: If you’ll excuse me. Arnold starts to walk away then remembers:

dialogues.speaker: ARNOLD
dialogues.text: Oh, Mr Lampard. I accept your resignation. Lampard is astonished.

dialogues.speaker: CUT TO
dialogues.text: INT - RUGBY SCHOOL/ARNOLD’S HOUSE/DINING ROOM - DAY 79 Tom knocks on the open door and enters Arnold’s study. Mary Arnold is pouring tea, cutting cake. Arnold is there, standing next to a skinny, odd-looking, around eleven. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tom Brown's Schooldays - Shooting Script 06.04.04 69A.

dialogues.speaker: ARNOLD
dialogues.text: There you are, Brown. I trust you left your father and mother well? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 79 Tom Brown's Schooldays - Shooting Script 06.04.04

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: Very, sir.

dialogues.speaker: ARNOLD
dialogues.text: I’d like you to meet George Arthur. 70. 79 Tom shakes the boy’s hand robustly. He gets a thin, damp return.

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: I believe that matron has put him in the bed next to yours.

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: That’s East’s bed.

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: Arthur has never been away from home before and I assured his mother that he would be well looked after. Tom has a lurching feeling in his stomach.

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: By me, ma’am?

dialogues.speaker: ARNOLD
dialogues.text: How very kind of you, Brown, I thought sure that would be your attitude. A word. Arnold gestures for him to come over to the window so tha can speak with some privacy.

dialogues.speaker: ARNOLD
dialogues.text: It does not seem so very long ago that we were both new here, does it? They both look down at the arriving schoolboys below.

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: No, sir.

dialogues.speaker: ARNOLD
dialogues.text: I remember it as a rather harsh, frightening place. Arthur’s father has recently died. He has no brothers, just a sister. I suspect he does not quite have your robust physical constitution. Tom looks at the spindly boy. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tom Brown's Schooldays - Shooting Script 06.04.04 71.

dialogues.speaker: ARNOLD
dialogues.text: Look after him. Do you think you can do that?

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: Yes, sir.

dialogues.speaker: ARNOLD
dialogues.text: Then I suspect we have an understanding.

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: (Not entirely happy) Yes, sir.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tom, East, Tadpole, Green etc are undressing for bed. Arthur is half-undressed, but staring at the other boys.

dialogues.speaker: ARTHUR
dialogues.text: Tom?

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: ARTHUR
dialogues.text: Where do I undress?

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: (Hissing) Here, stupid. East is not happy about his new bed by the window.

dialogues.speaker: EAST
dialogues.text: Why does he have to have my bed?

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: Because Mrs Arnold said so. Tom is pulling his shirt over his head so does not at fir what the others see: George Arthur is on his knees by his

dialogues.speaker: ARTHUR
dialogues.text: “Our Father which art in heaven, hallowed be thy name. Thy kingdom come.” (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tom Brown's Schooldays - Shooting Script 06.04.04 71A.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: The first boot hits Arthur on the back of the head. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 80 81 Tom Brown's Schooldays - Shooting Script 06.04.04 72.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: There are jeers and more shoes from the other boys.

dialogues.speaker: ARTHUR
dialogues.text: “Thy will be done on earth as it is in heaven. Give us this day our daily bread.” Tom feels for Arthur but more than anything he doesn’t wa lose face in front of his fellows.

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: Go to bed, Arthur. Arthur hesitates. The shoes and jeers rain down on him.

dialogues.speaker: ARTHUR
dialogues.text: “And forgive us our trespasses, as we forgive them that trespass against us. And lead us not into temptation. But deliver us from evil. Amen.” Arthur scampers into bed and pulls up his blanket. Tom says nothing. Blows out the candle.

dialogues.speaker: INT
dialogues.text: Flashman, Speedicot and others are roistering in the loca tavern, both of them bouncing PROSTITUTES on their knees. Bill comes into the tavern, walks over to Flashman.

dialogues.speaker: BILL
dialogues.text: A word, please, Mr Flashman.

dialogues.speaker: SPEEDICOT
dialogues.text: Hello, Bill! Have a drink.

dialogues.speaker: FLASHMAN
dialogues.text: Have a woman, Bill. I'll pay. Speedicot and Flashman laugh.

dialogues.speaker: BILL
dialogues.text: A word, please, sir. To Flashman’s surprise Bill takes him by the hand and dra away from Speedicot. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tom Brown's Schooldays - Shooting Script 06.04.04 72A.

dialogues.speaker: BILL
dialogues.text: You'll marry her, Mr Flashman, of course. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 81 82 Tom Brown's Schooldays - Shooting Script 06.04.04 73.

dialogues.speaker: FLASHMAN
dialogues.text: Marry whom?

dialogues.speaker: BILL
dialogues.text: Sally.

dialogues.speaker: FLASHMAN
dialogues.text: Sally? Why on earth would I want to marry Sally? No offence and all that but... Sally?

dialogues.speaker: BILL
dialogues.text: I think you know why, Mr Flashman.

dialogues.speaker: FLASHMAN
dialogues.text: Nothing that Sally says could be of the remotest interest to me, Bill. Now if you don’t mind I'd rather like to rejoin my -

dialogues.speaker: BILL
dialogues.text: I’1l go to the Doctor, you see if I don't. Flashman just looks at Bill. Then bursts into laughter.

dialogues.speaker: FLASHMAN
dialogues.text: Do you really think he would believe the word of the town slattern over that of an English gentleman? Bill strikes out at Flashman but before he can do any dam is wrestled to the floor by Speedicot and others.

dialogues.speaker: FLASHMAN
dialogues.text: I own the Doctor, Bill. Didn’t you know that? Flashman kicks the helpless Bill in the stomach.

dialogues.speaker: EXT
dialogues.text: A cricket match is in progress, East bowling and Tom cajo his team mates.

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: Come on, boys, last wicket! The tension in the pavilion is tense as the batting team on. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tom Brown's Schooldays - Shooting Script 06.04.04 73A.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: East bowls and the batsman hits high up into the summer s (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 82 83 Tom Brown's Schooldays - Shooting Script 06.04.04 74.

dialogues.speaker: EAST
dialogues.text: Catch it! Tom sees that the fielder nearest the ball is Arthur but not even following the game, he’s standing in the outfiel reading Greek.

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: Arthur! Catch! Startled by Tom’s voice, Arthur looks up.

dialogues.speaker: ARTHUR
dialogues.text: Sorry, Brown? The ball lands on the grass. There is a shocked silence.

dialogues.speaker: ARTHUR
dialogues.text: Do you want your ball? Then the victorious batting team start to laugh, pointing Arthur. East is beside himself with fury. He starts to run over t Arthur but is rugby-tackled by Tom before he can get ther Arthur returns to his book, oblivious.

dialogues.speaker: CUT TO
dialogues.text: INT - RUGBY SCHOOL/ARNOLD’S STUDY - DAY 83

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A very cocky Flashman is standing in front of Arnold.

dialogues.speaker: ARNOLD
dialogues.text: Is it true? The woman is with child.

dialogues.speaker: FLASHMAN
dialogues.text: (Laughs ) The girl flips onto her back for a penny, Headmaster. Why, half the men in town have -

dialogues.speaker: ARNOLD
dialogues.text: I am not asking about them, sir, I am asking about you. Have you lain with this young woman? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tom Brown's Schooldays - Shooting Script 06.04.04 74A.

dialogues.speaker: FLASHMAN
dialogues.text: (Amused) Lain, sir? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Tom Brown's Schooldays - Shooting Script 06.04.04 75. (2)

dialogues.speaker: ARNOLD
dialogues.text: Is there something amusing in this squalid circumstance? I fail to see it.

dialogues.speaker: FLASHMAN
dialogues.text: No, sir. Not lain. I don’t know who the poor sprog’s father is but it ain’t me. Arnold knows there is little he can do. A beat.

dialogues.speaker: ARNOLD
dialogues.text: You give me your word as a Christian and a gentleman?

dialogues.speaker: FLASHMAN
dialogues.text: Absolutely, sir.

dialogues.speaker: ARNOLD
dialogues.text: I will be watching you, Mr Flashman.

dialogues.speaker: FLASHMAN
dialogues.text: Will you, sir? Oh and pater said to say that the gymnasium equipment will be with us soon, sir. Will that be all? Arnold nods. Flashman smiles and leaves the study.

dialogues.speaker: CUT TO
dialogues.text: 84 Tom and Arthur are in separate baths, the water dirty and scummy.

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: You have to start learning the Rugby ways, Arthur, or your time here is going to be short and unpleasant.

dialogues.speaker: ARTHUR
dialogues.text: Do you miss your parents, Tom? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tom Brown's Schooldays - Shooting Script 06.04.04 75A.

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: (Appalled, looking around) There you again! Will you stop saying things like that? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tom Brown's Schooldays - Shooting Script 06.04.04 76.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Arthur shrugs, serene.

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: You have to stand up for yourself. Be a man.

dialogues.speaker: ARTHUR
dialogues.text: Like you?

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: I can’t watch your back for ever.

dialogues.speaker: ARTHUR
dialogues.text: It would be a dull old World if we all had to be the same, wouldn't it, Tom?

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: If a fellow hits you, hit him back.

dialogues.speaker: ARTHUR
dialogues.text: I don’t believe in violence.

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: (Exasperated) Of course you believe in violence! You're British. Look, there’s nothing to be afraid of -

dialogues.speaker: ARTHUR
dialogues.text: I’m not afraid of anything, Tom. Huband appears in the washroom.

dialogues.speaker: HUBAND
dialogues.text: Out, Brown, stop fermenting in your own filth. And you, Arthur. (Shouts ) Next! A couple of boys in dressing-gowns present themselves for next use of the dirty water. Huband leaves.

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: (Warning) You're a very strange fellow, Arthur, and strangeness doesn’t flourish here.

dialogues.speaker: CUT TO
dialogues.text: 85 86 Tom Brown's Schooldays - Shooting Script 06.04.04 77.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sound of a carriage shuddering by. Bill is locking up the main gates of the school, waves up coachman. He notices a bundle on the ground. Bill walks over and realises it is a person. He pulls bac hood to realise with horror that it is Sally, her face wh her eyes closed.

dialogues.speaker: BILL
dialogues.text: Sally?

dialogues.speaker: CUT TO
dialogues.text: INT - RUGBY SCHOOL/MATRON’S SICK ROOM - NIGHT 86

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Matron gently cleans her daughter’s unconscious face as t worried Bill looks on. Arnold is huddled just outside the sick room with Mary. *

dialogues.speaker: ARNOLD
dialogues.text: (Shocked) * An abortion? * Mary nods, angry and upset. *

dialogues.speaker: ARNOLD
dialogues.text: And Sally? *

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: She’s lost a lot of blood but she’11l * live. *

dialogues.speaker: ARNOLD
dialogues.text: Who paid for it? *

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: (Angry ) * Who do you think? *

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Arnold looks in at the sad sight.

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: (Pointed) This is monstrous and something must be done about it. + eH (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tom Brown's Schooldays - Shooting Script 06.04.04 77A.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Mary walks by Arnold to help with Sally.

dialogues.speaker: CUT TO
dialogues.text: 87 Tom Brown's Schooldays - Shooting Script 06.04.04 78.

dialogues.speaker: INT
dialogues.text: 87 Smith is listening to Arthur as he construes from the Ili really enjoying the boy’s clarity and rhythm. East is drawing scenes of football, Tom watching Arthur w baffled respect.

dialogues.speaker: ARTHUR
dialogues.text: (Reading) “Thus did he pray, and Apollo heard his prayer. He came down furious from the summits of Olympus, with his bow and his quiver upon his shoulder, and the arrows rattled on his back with the rage that trembled within him.” To everyone’s amazement Arthur stands up and starts playi the scenes as he speaks. The boys have never seen their lessons “come to life” like this and one-by-one start to wake up and laugh at Arthur’s ant East just shakes his head: weird boy. Tom starts to enjoy the theatrical performance, for the f time sees a glimpse of popularity in Arthur.

dialogues.speaker: ARTHUR
dialogues.text: “His silver bow rang death as he shot his arrow in the midst of them. First he smote their mules and their hounds, but presently he aimed his shafts at the people themselves, and all day long the pyres of the dead were burning.” Arthur sits down with a theatrical gesture.

dialogues.speaker: SMITH
dialogues.text: (Amused) If you’re quite finished, Arthur.

dialogues.speaker: ARTHUR
dialogues.text: Quite, sir.

dialogues.speaker: CUT TO
dialogues.text: 88 89 90 Tom Brown's Schooldays - Shooting Script 06.04.04 79.

dialogues.speaker: INT
dialogues.text: Arthur is at his bed, praying, as he does every night. East thinks it is hilarious to thrash Arthur on the backs with his shoe. Tom comes in to the dorm, sees what is happening, takes t from East and promptly throws it out of the window. All the boys laugh, pointing at East rather than Arthur.

dialogues.speaker: EXT
dialogues.text: Some “stumps” have been chalked on a door and East is bow Tom. *

dialogues.speaker: EAST
dialogues.text: He’s weird, that’s all there is to it.

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: He’s a bit... different.

dialogues.speaker: EAST
dialogues.text: He should be in an asylum not a school.

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: It would be a dull old World if we all had to be the same, wouldn’t it? To East’s irritation Tom whacks the cricket ball back har making him duck. *

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There is a murmur of noise as boys read on their own or c together. Arthur is on his own, ensconced in Ovid. Flashman and Speedicot come into the school house and sta the master’s desk. Flashman takes a letter out of his pocket with a flourish (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 90 91 92 Tom Brown's Schooldays - Shooting Script 06.04.04 80.

dialogues.speaker: FLASHMAN
dialogues.text: (Reading) “My dearest, dearest Mama...” Boys look up at this, sense some fun and cruelty in the a Arthur continues to study, oblivious.

dialogues.speaker: FLASHMAN
dialogues.text: (Reading) “I won’t pretend that every moment of my life at Rugby has been a happy one but I believe there are some shards of sunshine in the darkness...” Much laughter from the boys.

dialogues.speaker: FLASHMAN
dialogues.text: (Reading) “That sunshine has a name, Mama. It is Tom Brown”. Howls of laughter from the boys now. Arthur looks up, knows that Flashman has intercepted his home to his mother. Tadpole looks over at Arthur, knows he is in trouble.

dialogues.speaker: EXT
dialogues.text: East and Tom are looking for the cricket ball in the door off the corridor.

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: Got it?

dialogues.speaker: EAST
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Flashman continues to read from the letter as Arthur, jee and reviled, tries to maintain his dignity. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tom Brown's Schooldays - Shooting Script 06.04.04 80A.

dialogues.speaker: FLASHMAN
dialogues.text: (Reading) “Doctor Arnold has ‘cast off the work of darkness and let us put on the armour of light’ ". (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tom Brown's Schooldays - Shooting Script 06.04.04 81.

dialogues.speaker: SPEEDICOT
dialogues.text: You mean by destroying our school, you little scud?

dialogues.speaker: FLASHMAN
dialogues.text: (Reading) “I think he means to make it a more diverse place, where all sorts of flowers will be able to bloom”. Flashman walks towards Arthur who looks around for his fr

dialogues.speaker: SPEEDICOT
dialogues.text: What shall we do with the little flower, Flashy?

dialogues.speaker: FLASHMAN
dialogues.text: What do we do with flowers? We water them! Tadpole slips out.

dialogues.speaker: EXT
dialogues.text: Tom holds up the ball.

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: Found it!

dialogues.speaker: EAST
dialogues.text: Don’t do it again. Tom sees Tadpole panting into the corridor, knows instant something is wrong.

dialogues.speaker: EAST
dialogues.text: What is it, Tadpole?

dialogues.speaker: TADPOLE
dialogues.text: Flashman’s got Arthur.

dialogues.speaker: EXT
dialogues.text: The cover is being wheeled from the old well. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tom Brown's Schooldays - Shooting Script 06.04.04 81A.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Arthur is trussed up in rope, his arms pinned to his side (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 94 Tom Brown's Schooldays - Shooting Script 06.04.04 82.

dialogues.speaker: FLASHMAN
dialogues.text: If he doesn’t drown he’s guilty of treason to Rugby School. If he does.... then we’re all most frightfully sorry. Flashman gives a signal and Arthur is lowered down into t dark, cold well. Boys rush to look over the rim of the well, peering into darkness. A beat then a splashing noise.

dialogues.speaker: SPEEDICOT
dialogues.text: I think he’s in the water, Flashy.

dialogues.speaker: FLASHMAN
dialogues.text: Then give the chap a good dunk. They jerk the rope up and down and we can hear splashing

dialogues.speaker: SPEEDICOT
dialogues.text: Bring him up.

dialogues.speaker: FLASHMAN
dialogues.text: One more. For luck. Again they jerk the rope up and down. Tom and East come running around the corner.

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: Bring him up, you cowards! The Boys look instantly guilty, start to haul Arthur up.

dialogues.speaker: FLASHMAN
dialogues.text: Look who it is, the shard of light in our miserable lives.

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: You're a brute, Flashman. Arthur is pulled up, chattering with cold. Tom and East go to him at once, concerned.

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: Are you alright? Speedicot makes kissing noises. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 94 Tom Brown's Schooldays - Shooting Script 06.04.04 83.

dialogues.speaker: FLASHMAN
dialogues.text: Would you like me to buy you a woman, Brown? Then you wouldn’t have to go sniffing around little boys. Tom turns and looks at Flashman, eyes sparkling with ange

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: I’ve had enough of you, Flashman.

dialogues.speaker: FLASHMAN
dialogues.text: What are you going to do? Shine on me?

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: I’m going to beat you. Will you fight? A frisson of surprise and excitement goes around the boys

dialogues.speaker: FLASHMAN
dialogues.text: Fight with you?

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: Are you man enough?

dialogues.speaker: FLASHMAN
dialogues.text: I’m in the Fifth, I don’t fight fleas like you.

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: So you’re a coward as well as a brute?

dialogues.speaker: SPEEDICOT
dialogues.text: Fight him, Flashy, if that’s what he wants. Flashman hates being put into this position, feels the ey his friends on him.

dialogues.speaker: FLASHMAN
dialogues.text: I’m going to kill you, Brown. A great cheer goes up. Fight! Boys run to tell their frie

dialogues.speaker: ARTHUR
dialogues.text: I don’t want you to do this.

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: He’s had it coming to him.

dialogues.speaker: CUT TO
dialogues.text: 95 96 97 Tom Brown's Schooldays - Shooting Script 06.04.04 84. INT - RUGBY SCHOOL/ARNOLD’S STUDY - DAY 95 Arnold is at work on a sermon in the peace of his study, old clock for company. Spot the dog twitches and opens his eyes. He’s heard some

dialogues.speaker: EXT
dialogues.text: Hundreds of boys have formed a circle, excited, chatting. East looks after Tom, taking his jacket and talking to hi The much larger Flashman hands his jacket to Speedicot.

dialogues.speaker: EAST
dialogues.text: Fight with your head. He’s bigger than you are but he’s unfit. Don’t go steaming in, just jab, jab, wait for your moment. Speedicot walks forward.

dialogues.speaker: SPEEDICOT
dialogues.text: Gentlemen, begin!

dialogues.speaker: EAST
dialogues.text: With your head, Tom, keep outside his range and - But Tom hasn’t listened to a word. He goes directly for F and lands a barrage of blows to the astonished young man’ East shakes his head. The younger boys cheer, love seeing Flashman getting hit. Angry, Flashman retaliates with some nasty slogs of his o

dialogues.speaker: EAST
dialogues.text: Feet, Tom!

dialogues.speaker: INT
dialogues.text: The dormitory is empty, everyone is at the fight. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 97 98 99 Tom Brown's Schooldays - Shooting Script 06.04.04 85.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: A very unhappy Arthur peels off his jacket. He is sodden, teeth chattering with cold.

dialogues.speaker: EXT
dialogues.text: Arnold is walking across the quad when he hears the shout the boys at the fight. He steps back, careful not to be seen.

dialogues.speaker: EXT
dialogues.text: The fight is in full swing, blood pouring from both Tom a Flashman's faces. The boys are cheering and clapping.

dialogues.speaker: EAST
dialogues.text: Go on, Tom!

dialogues.speaker: SPEEDICOT
dialogues.text: Finish him off, Flashy! The youngsters are really getting behind Tom now, their h pummelling the larger, out-of-condition Flashman. Tom ducks inside a punch from the tiring Flashman and bel on the nose, blood spraying everywhere.

dialogues.speaker: SPEEDICOT
dialogues.text: Time!

dialogues.speaker: EAST
dialogues.text: (Outraged) No, it’s not! Flashman staggers back to Speedicot and his corner, his d clothes spattered in blood.

dialogues.speaker: EAST
dialogues.text: You’ve got him, Tom! He’s blowing like a whale. Just don’t be in a hurry, wait for your opening. Tom nods, spits out his water, pink with his own blood. Flashman is in a bad way and doesn’t fancy much more. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 99 100 101 Tom Brown's Schooldays - Shooting Script 06.04.04 86.

dialogues.speaker: FLASHMAN
dialogues.text: (Whispering, to Speedicot) The dusters. Speedicot looks around, very wary of anyone overhearing.

dialogues.speaker: SPEEDICOT
dialogues.text: You’ve got him, Flashy.

dialogues.speaker: FLASHMAN
dialogues.text: (Hissing) Give me them. Speedicot surreptitiously slips some large, brass knuckle dusters into Flashman’s hand.

dialogues.speaker: SPEEDICOT
dialogues.text: Time! Tom and Flashman stand up.

dialogues.speaker: EXT
dialogues.text: Arnold watches the fight as Frobisher hurries across the

dialogues.speaker: FROBISHER
dialogues.text: Brown and Flashman are fighting, sir.

dialogues.speaker: ARNOLD
dialogues.text: So I see. Do you know why?

dialogues.speaker: FROBISHER
dialogues.text: Something to do with young Arthur, sir. You know, the new boy. Shall I go and stop it, sir? A beat as Arnold considers.

dialogues.speaker: ARNOLD
dialogues.text: No. Frobisher is taken aback by Arnold’s answer.

dialogues.speaker: EXT
dialogues.text: The boys cheer Tom on as his punches force Flashman back back. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 101 102 Tom Brown's Schooldays - Shooting Script 06.04.04 87.

dialogues.speaker: SPEEDICOT
dialogues.text: Hit him back, Flashy!

dialogues.speaker: EAST
dialogues.text: He’s yours, Tom! Flashman slips his hand into his pocket and comes out wit knuckle-dusters slipped onto his fist. He smacks Tom in the face and the brass cuts into Tom’s s forehead. East is alarmed.

dialogues.speaker: EAST
dialogues.text: Tom? Now Flashman has the advantage and a flurry of right-hook the brass slamming into Tom’s face, blood bursting everyw Tom’s legs wobble and he goes down. East is quickly at his side, not noticing Flashman slippi knuckle-dusters into his pocket.

dialogues.speaker: EAST
dialogues.text: Are you alright, Tom? Tom? Tom is barely conscious.

dialogues.speaker: INT
dialogues.text: Arnold has seen what has happened, watches with concern a younger boys crowd around Tom. Suddenly Flashman turns around and runs and kicks Tom in stomach. The knuckledusters slip from his hand and clatter onto th cobbles. * All the boys look at them, appalled, them up at Flashman’

dialogues.speaker: FLASHMAN
dialogues.text: All’s fair in love and war. * East is outraged and goes for Flashman but Tadpole and Gr hold him back.

dialogues.speaker: CUT TO
dialogues.text: Tom Brown's Schooldays - Shooting Script 06.04.04 87A.

dialogues.speaker: INT
dialogues.text: Arthur is shivering in his underwear. He suddenly collapses.

dialogues.speaker: CUT TO
dialogues.text: 104 105 106 107 Tom Brown's Schooldays - Shooting Script 06.04.04 88.

dialogues.speaker: EXT
dialogues.text: The great trees sway in the wind. The school is dark, silent, sombre.

dialogues.speaker: INT
dialogues.text: Silence in the dormitory. The boys are all in bed, the candle on. Tom is wide awake, turns on his back to look at Arthur’s bed. Smith comes into the room to extinguish the light.

dialogues.speaker: SMITH
dialogues.text: Good night, boys.

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: Any news, sir?

dialogues.speaker: SMITH
dialogues.text: Not yet. Good night.

dialogues.speaker: BOYS
dialogues.text: Good night, sir. Smith blows out the light.

dialogues.speaker: CUT TO
dialogues.text: INT - RUGBY SCHOOL/MATRON’S SICK ROOM - NIGHT 106 Arthur is unconscious in the sick room. Matron makes the boy comfortable as a very worried Doctor his temperature again.

dialogues.speaker: CUT TO
dialogues.text: INT - RUGBY SCHOOL/ARNOLD’S STUDY - NIGHT 107 Arnold stands in front of Flashman. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tom Brown's Schooldays - Shooting Script 06.04.04 88A.

dialogues.speaker: FLASHMAN
dialogues.text: Brown is an uppity little cad and he had it coming to him. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 107 108 Tom Brown's Schooldays - Shooting Script 06.04.04 89.

dialogues.speaker: ARNOLD
dialogues.text: You are a coward and a bully, Flashman. I am going to do now what I should have done a long time ago.

dialogues.speaker: FLASHMAN
dialogues.text: If you cane me, sir, my father will hear about it.

dialogues.speaker: ARNOLD
dialogues.text: I won't be caning you. Flashman looks relieved at this.

dialogues.speaker: ARNOLD
dialogues.text: Go to your dormitory, pack a bag and leave the school at once. The rest of your belongings will be sent on. Flashman is shocked to the core by this.

dialogues.speaker: FLASHMAN
dialogues.text: (Angry) Have you any idea who I am, sir? Arnold looks Flashman steadily, contemptuously in the eye

dialogues.speaker: ARNOLD
dialogues.text: I know exactly who you are, sir. Get out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bill opens the main gate of the school to let Flashman ou

dialogues.speaker: FLASHMAN
dialogues.text: Lovely night, Bill. Flashman walks cockily away from the school, trying to sh doesn’t care, his bag in his hand. Suddenly he is pelted with mud and rotten eggs as dozens small, bullied boys break cover and attack Flashman. Flashman covers his face, frightened. The boys race back through the gate and into the safety o school, leaving Flashman dirty and bedraggled. Bill locks the gate. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tom Brown's Schooldays - Shooting Script 06.04.04 90.

dialogues.speaker: BILL
dialogues.text: Lovely night, Mr Flashman. Flashman looks back to see Tom Brown looking at him from darkness of the school walls. Tom looks directly into Flashman’s eyes, staring him out, Flashman breaks off and skulks away down the street. *

dialogues.speaker: CUT TO
dialogues.text: 109 INT - RUGBY SCHOOL/MATRON’S SICK ROOM - NIGHT 109 Tom lowers himself quietly into the room, creeps over to Arthur’s bed.

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: (Gentle) Arthur. Arthur. Arthur stirs.

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: It’s me, Arthur. Tom. How are you? You gave us fellows a hell of a shock with your fainting tactic.

dialogues.speaker: ARTHUR
dialogues.text: Did he hurt you?

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: Flashman? Not a bit. A shiver seems to wrack Arthur’s body, alarming Tom.

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: Arthur? Arthur seems to slip off into a deep sleep.

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: (Alarmed) Arthur? Arnold is standing in the room, has watched some of this.

dialogues.speaker: ARNOLD
dialogues.text: Let him sleep now. Tom jumps to his feet, had no idea Arnold was there. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tom Brown's Schooldays - Shooting Script 06.04.04 90A.

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: Will he be alright, sir? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 109 Tom Brown's Schooldays - Shooting Script 06.04.04 91.

dialogues.speaker: ARNOLD
dialogues.text: Only God can answer that. All we can do is pray for him.

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: It’s all my fault.

dialogues.speaker: ARNOLD
dialogues.text: Your fault?

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: I was meant to be looking after him! They put him down the well and -

dialogues.speaker: ARNOLD
dialogues.text: It’s not your fault, Brown. It appears Arthur had a medical condition that preceded his time here. Tom turns to look at Arthur.

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: He will get better. I know he will.

dialogues.speaker: ARNOLD
dialogues.text: Go back to your dormitory.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tom, East, Tadpole, Green and the others are all sat in t desks. Smith is at the master’s table, declaiming Greek to the distracted boys. Tom looks over at Arthur’s empty seat. Little Weston comes into the School House with a note and boy watches him walk up to Smith with trepidation. Smith takes the note and reads it.

dialogues.speaker: SMITH
dialogues.text: Brown. The Headmaster would like to see you in his house.

dialogues.speaker: CUT TO
dialogues.text: Tom Brown's Schooldays - Shooting Script 06.04.04 92.

dialogues.speaker: INT
dialogues.text: Tom lets himself into the Arnold’s drawing room. Arnold and Mary are both there, turn to look at him.

dialogues.speaker: ARNOLD
dialogues.text: Come in, Brown. Tom notices that there is another woman in the room, youn very beautiful. She looks tired but her eyes watch Tom co the room with great interest. This is FRANCES, Arthur’s m At her side is a very pretty girl of about his age.

dialogues.speaker: ARNOLD
dialogues.text: This is Arthur’s mother and his sister, Charlotte. Frances puts her hand out to Tom.

dialogues.speaker: FRANCES
dialogues.text: I believe that Charlotte and myself owe you a great debt of gratitude for looking after our dear boy these last weeks. Arnold and Mary exchange a glance of pride at this.

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: Is he better, ma’am?

dialogues.speaker: FRANCES
dialogues.text: A little. He’s asking for you. Tom looks at Arnold and Arnold nods.

dialogues.speaker: ARNOLD
dialogues.text: Just for a while, we must not tire him. Tom is excited, about to leave.

dialogues.speaker: FRANCES
dialogues.text: Thank you again, Tom. From both of us. Charlotte flashes Tom a look.

dialogues.speaker: CUT TO
dialogues.text: Tom Brown's Schooldays - Shooting Script 06.04.04 93. 112 INT - RUGBY SCHOOL/MATRON’S SICK ROOM - DAY 112

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tom sits next to Arthur’s bed.

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: I don’t know where they’1l bat me but at least I’m in the team.

dialogues.speaker: ARTHUR
dialogues.text: You're the best bat in School House, you should go in first. Tom smiles at this. Tom nods.

dialogues.speaker: ARTHUR
dialogues.text: Did you like my mother, Tom?

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: Very much.

dialogues.speaker: ARTHUR
dialogues.text: And Charlotte? Did you like her?

dialogues.speaker: ARTHUR
dialogues.text: If anything should happen to me will you promise that you will look after them? You're very good at that.

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: Nothing’s going to happen to you, stupid. Don’t talk that way.

dialogues.speaker: ARTHUR
dialogues.text: I’m not afraid of dying.

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: Arthur -

dialogues.speaker: ARTHUR
dialogues.text: I’m not afraid of my friends dying, either. Because one day we will all die and be together for ever. Arthur is feverish, mumbling.

dialogues.speaker: ARTHUR
dialogues.text: I had this dream, Tom. A river. Green fields. Everyone I have ever known was there. You and Harry - (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 112 113 Tom Brown's Schooldays - Shooting Script 06.04.04 94.

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: (Changing subject) Did you hear Flashman got sent down?

dialogues.speaker: ARTHUR
dialogues.text: Even Flashman. He was there. Even Flashman. And the Doctor. And mother and Charlotte. And my father. Everyone we have ever known will be there. Tom is uncomfortable and out of his depth. Matron comes in to the sick room.

dialogues.speaker: MATRON
dialogues.text: That’s enough now Brown. Tom nods and she leaves them.

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: I have to go, Arthur. I’1l come back as soon as they let me. Arthur’s hand finds Tom’s.

dialogues.speaker: ARTHUR
dialogues.text: Will you do something for me, Tom?

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: Anything, you know that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The boys are getting ready for bed, talking quietly, not normal rowdy selves. Tom is lying in his bed, agitated. He gets up, drops to his knees by his bed and prayers.

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: (Praying) “Our Father which art in Heaven, hallowed be thy name. Thy kingdom come.” East and Tadpole and the others look on, astonished, at t sight of Tom Brown praying. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 113 114 Tom Brown's Schooldays - Shooting Script 06.04.04 95.

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: “Thy will be done on earth as it is in Heaven. Give us this day our daily bread.” East kneels down next to Tom and joins him in prayer. No- jeers, no-one throws shoes.

dialogues.speaker: TOM EAST
dialogues.text: And forgive us our And forgive us our trespasses, as we forgive trespasses, as we forgive them that trespass against them that trespass against us. And lead us not into us. And lead us not into temptation. But deliver us temptation. But deliver us from evil. from evil. East stops praying, looks at his friend whose eyes are st clenched tight.

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: Please, Lord. Please let George Arthur live. One by the one the boys get under their blankets, the moo sombre and serious.

dialogues.speaker: INT
dialogues.text: Tom is getting changed for cricket with other boys from S House. East looks over at his friend, concerned. Tom seems distracted, not his usual rumbustious self. All the boys stand as Arnold comes into the pavilion. He addresses them all but his words are really for Tom.

dialogues.speaker: ARNOLD
dialogues.text: I thought you would like to know that I have just spoken to the Doctor and Arthur is sat up in bed and eating a hearty breakfast. This is indeed good news and Tom breaks into a smile.

dialogues.speaker: ARNOLD
dialogues.text: Enjoy the game, gentlemen.

dialogues.speaker: CUT TO
dialogues.text: Tom Brown's Schooldays - Shooting Script 06.04.04 96.

dialogues.speaker: EXT
dialogues.text: Tom and East are batting together, full of life and vigou skill. Tom smashes another ball to the boundary where it is gree with applause from the boys watching.

dialogues.speaker: CUT TO
dialogues.text: INT - RUGBY SCHOOL/MATRON’S SICK ROOM - DAY 116 The windows are open and the applause and the sound of To Brown’s bat on ball drift up from the playing field below Arthur lies in his sick bed, smiles at the noise. His mother is reading to him from “Pickwick Papers” as Ch walks to the window and looks down on the cricketers belo

dialogues.speaker: FRANCES
dialogues.text: (Reading) * “And in the midst of all this, stood * Mr. Pickwick, his countenance lighted up with smiles, which the heart of no man, woman, or child, could resist: himself the happiest of the group: shaking hands, over and over again, with the same people, and when his own hands were not so employed, rubbing them with pleasure”. * Tom drives another ball to the boundary.

dialogues.speaker: BOYS
dialogues.text: Well played, Brown! Arthur closes his eyes, lets the sound of Rugby School on Summer’s day drift over him as his mother reads.

dialogues.speaker: INT
dialogues.text: Cheerful chaos in the School House as the victorious cric team mix with their colleagues, eating and drinking and l about. Sunlight pours in through the windows. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tom Brown's Schooldays - Shooting Script 06.04.04 96A.

dialogues.speaker: EAST
dialogues.text: I’m thinking duck, duck you fool and he whacks it over square leg like he was swatting a fly! The laughter stops as Doctor Arnold comes into the room a all stand. Tom and East look at each other, have never seen Arnold h a meal time. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tom Brown's Schooldays - Shooting Script 06.04.04 97.

dialogues.speaker: ARNOLD
dialogues.text: It is my sad duty to tell you that George Arthur of Rugby School died this afternoon. The shock is rigid on the boys’ faces. Tom can’t believe it, just stares at Arnold.

dialogues.speaker: ARNOLD
dialogues.text: He will be buried in the chapel. I wish... Arnold would like to say more but he can’t find the words He turns and leaves the room, closing the door behind him A shocked, stunned beat. Then Thomas Brown - brave, fearless Tom - starts to cry l baby, his sobs echoing in the great School House. East puts his arm around his friend, fiercely loyal, dari anyone to say anything. But the boys are paralysed with grief and dread.

dialogues.speaker: CUT TO
dialogues.text: INT - RUGBY SCHOOL/TOM’S STUDY - NIGHT 118 Tom stands alone in his study, his face ashen, drained. A beat. Then he starts to destroy the study in a fury of anger an The door opens and Arnold is standing there. His eyes quickly take in the situation but he says nothin

dialogues.speaker: ARNOLD
dialogues.text: Will you forget Arthur?

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: (Fierce) Never, sir.

dialogues.speaker: ARNOLD
dialogues.text: Nor shall I. Nor shall any one of us who met him and was touched by him. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tom Brown's Schooldays - Shooting Script 06.04.04 97A.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Tom nods, trying to understand. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 120 Tom Brown's Schooldays - Shooting Script 06.04.04 98.

dialogues.speaker: ARNOLD
dialogues.text: Be strong tomorrow. Arthur would expect it of you and the school will need it of you. Tom nods, very touched by this faith in him. Arnold goes to leave.

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: Good night, sir.

dialogues.speaker: ARNOLD
dialogues.text: Good night. Tom. Tom and Arnold look at each other with a great mutual res Arnold leaves Tom’s study.

dialogues.speaker: INT
dialogues.text: The chapel is full to bursting with every boy and Master school. Arnold is at his lectern. Frances and Charlotte sit at the front of the chapel. The school hymn is being sung. Tom and East, Tadpole and Green, carry the coffin into th chapel. Tom Brown looks at Doctor Arnold and a look of deep understanding exists between man and boy. Tom sings with gusto and strength, inspiring his friends.

dialogues.speaker: EXT
dialogues.text: The grounds are deserted, every boy and master in the cha The sound of the school hymn drifts in the breeze. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tom Brown's Schooldays - Shooting Script 06.04.04 99.
